editorial.editors_note: As we retreat into custom-built silos to patch the structural leaks of open-source reliability, we are reminded that true security is rarely found in the convenience of the collective.
editorial.emphasis: The transition from universal frameworks to bespoke, localized hardware sovereignty.

top_candidates.original_title: I ditched OpenClaw and built a more secure AI agent (Blink and Mac Mini)
top_candidates.generated_headline: Engineer Replaces OpenClaw with Custom Mac Mini–Blink Agent, Citing Security Gaps in Open-Source Frameworks
top_candidates.summary: A developer abandoned the OpenClaw AI agent framework due to perceived architectural vulnerabilities, opting instead for a self-hosted solution combining a Mac Mini and Blink’s sandboxing. The move underscores persistent tradeoffs between open-source convenience and control over attack surfaces in production AI systems.

top_candidates.original_title: Cloudflare adds real-time Markdown rendering for AI agents
top_candidates.generated_headline: Cloudflare extends edge compute to real-time Markdown sanitization for LLM outputs
top_candidates.summary: By shifting Markdown rendering to the edge, Cloudflare reduces client-side compute overhead for AI agents, though it introduces a potential centralized failure point in the presentation layer.
